akka-persistence

  1. ###########################################################
  2. # Akka Persistence Extension Reference Configuration File #
  3. ###########################################################
  4.  
  5. # This is the reference config file that contains all the default settings.
  6. # Make your edits in your application.conf in order to override these settings.
  7.  
  8. # Directory of persistence journal and snapshot store plugins is available at the 
  9. # Akka Community Projects page http://akka.io/community/
  10.  
  11. # Default persistence extension settings.
  12. akka.persistence {
  13.     journal {
  14.         # Absolute path to the journal plugin configuration entry used by 
  15.         # persistent actor or view by default.
  16.         # Persistent actor or view can override `journalPluginId` method 
  17.         # in order to rely on a different journal plugin.
  18.         plugin = ""
  19.     }
  20.     snapshot-store {
  21.         # Absolute path to the snapshot plugin configuration entry used by
  22.         # persistent actor or view by default.
  23.         # Persistent actor or view can override `snapshotPluginId` method
  24.         # in order to rely on a different snapshot plugin.
  25.         # It is not mandatory to specify a snapshot store plugin.
  26.         # If you don't use snapshots you don't have to configure it.
  27.         # Note that Cluster Sharding is using snapshots, so if you
  28.         # use Cluster Sharding you need to define a snapshot store plugin. 
  29.         plugin = ""
  30.     }
  31.     # used as default-snapshot store if no plugin configured 
  32.     # (see `akka.persistence.snapshot-store`)
  33.     no-snapshot-store {
  34.       class = "akka.persistence.snapshot.NoSnapshotStore"
  35.     }
  36.     # Default persistent view settings.
  37.     view {
  38.         # Automated incremental view update.
  39.         auto-update = on
  40.         # Interval between incremental updates.
  41.         auto-update-interval = 5s
  42.         # Maximum number of messages to replay per incremental view update. 
  43.         # Set to -1 for no upper limit.
  44.         auto-update-replay-max = -1
  45.     }
  46.     # Default reliable delivery settings.
  47.     at-least-once-delivery {
  48.         # Interval between re-delivery attempts.
  49.         redeliver-interval = 5s
  50.         # Maximum number of unconfirmed messages that will be sent in one 
  51.         # re-delivery burst.
  52.         redelivery-burst-limit = 10000
  53.         # After this number of delivery attempts a 
  54.         # `ReliableRedelivery.UnconfirmedWarning`, message will be sent to the actor.
  55.         warn-after-number-of-unconfirmed-attempts = 5
  56.         # Maximum number of unconfirmed messages that an actor with 
  57.         # AtLeastOnceDelivery is allowed to hold in memory.
  58.         max-unconfirmed-messages = 100000
  59.     }
  60.     # Default persistent extension thread pools.
  61.     dispatchers {
  62.         # Dispatcher used by every plugin which does not declare explicit
  63.         # `plugin-dispatcher` field.
  64.         default-plugin-dispatcher {
  65.             type = PinnedDispatcher
  66.             executor = "thread-pool-executor"
  67.         }
  68.         # Default dispatcher for message replay.
  69.         default-replay-dispatcher {
  70.             type = Dispatcher
  71.             executor = "fork-join-executor"
  72.             fork-join-executor {
  73.                 parallelism-min = 2
  74.                 parallelism-max = 8
  75.             }
  76.         }
  77.         # Default dispatcher for streaming snapshot IO
  78.         default-stream-dispatcher {
  79.             type = Dispatcher
  80.             executor = "fork-join-executor"
  81.             fork-join-executor {
  82.                 parallelism-min = 2
  83.                 parallelism-max = 8
  84.             }
  85.         }
  86.     }
  87.     
  88.     # Fallback settings for journal plugin configurations.
  89.     # These settings are used if they are not defined in plugin config section.
  90.     journal-plugin-fallback {
  91.     
  92.       # Fully qualified class name providing journal plugin api implementation.
  93.       # It is mandatory to specify this property.
  94.       # The class must have a constructor without parameters or constructor with
  95.       # one `com.typesafe.config.Config` parameter.
  96.       class = ""
  97.  
  98.       # Dispatcher for the plugin actor.
  99.       plugin-dispatcher = "akka.persistence.dispatchers.default-plugin-dispatcher"
  100.       
  101.       # Dispatcher for message replay.
  102.       replay-dispatcher = "akka.persistence.dispatchers.default-replay-dispatcher"
  103.       
  104.       # Maximum size of a persistent message batch written to the journal.
  105.       max-message-batch-size = 200
  106.       
  107.       circuit-breaker {
  108.         max-failures = 10
  109.         call-timeout = 10s
  110.         reset-timeout = 30s
  111.       }
  112.       
  113.       # The replay filter can detect a corrupt event stream by inspecting 
  114.       # sequence numbers and writerUuid when replaying events. 
  115.       replay-filter {
  116.         # What the filter should do when detecting invalid events.
  117.         # Supported values:
  118.         # `repair-by-discard-old` : discard events from old writers, 
  119.         #                           warning is logged
  120.         # `fail` : fail the replay, error is logged
  121.         # `warn` : log warning but emit events untouched
  122.         # `off` : disable this feature completely
  123.         mode = repair-by-discard-old
  124.           
  125.         # It uses a look ahead buffer for analyzing the events.
  126.         # This defines the size (in number of events) of the buffer.
  127.         window-size = 100
  128.           
  129.         # How many old writerUuid to remember
  130.         max-old-writers = 10
  131.       }
  132.     }
  133.  
  134.     # Fallback settings for snapshot store plugin configurations
  135.     # These settings are used if they are not defined in plugin config section.

  139.       # implementation. It is mandatory to specify this property if
  140.       # snapshot store is enabled.
  141.       # The class must have a constructor without parameters or constructor with
  142.       # one `com.typesafe.config.Config` parameter.
  143.       class = ""
  144.  
  145.       # Dispatcher for the plugin actor.
  146.       plugin-dispatcher = "akka.persistence.dispatchers.default-plugin-dispatcher"
  147.       
  148.       circuit-breaker {
  149.         max-failures = 5
  150.         call-timeout = 20s
  151.         reset-timeout = 60s
  152.       }
  153.     }

akka-remote

  1. #####################################
  2. # Akka Remote Reference Config File #
  3. #####################################
  4.  
  5. # This is the reference config file that contains all the default settings.
  6. # Make your edits/overrides in your application.conf.
  7.  
  8. # comments about akka.actor settings left out where they are already in akka-
  9. # actor.jar, because otherwise they would be repeated in config rendering.
  10.  
  11. akka {
  12.  
  13.   actor {
  14.  
  15.     serializers {
  16.       akka-containers = "akka.remote.serialization.MessageContainerSerializer"
  17.       proto = "akka.remote.serialization.ProtobufSerializer"
  18.       daemon-create = "akka.remote.serialization.DaemonMsgCreateSerializer"
  19.     }
  20.  
  21.     serialization-bindings {
  22.       "akka.actor.ActorSelectionMessage" = akka-containers
  23.       "akka.remote.DaemonMsgCreate" = daemon-create
  24.     
  25.       # Since akka.protobuf.Message does not extend Serializable but
  26.       # GeneratedMessage does, need to use the more specific one here in order
  27.       # to avoid ambiguity.
  28.       "akka.protobuf.GeneratedMessage" = proto
  29.       
  30.       # Since com.google.protobuf.Message does not extend Serializable but
  31.       # GeneratedMessage does, need to use the more specific one here in order
  32.       # to avoid ambiguity.
  33.       # This com.google.protobuf serialization binding is only used if the class can be loaded,
  34.       # i.e. com.google.protobuf dependency has been added in the application project.
  35.       "com.google.protobuf.GeneratedMessage" = proto
  36.       
  37.     }
  38.  
  39.     serialization-identifiers {
  40.       "akka.remote.serialization.ProtobufSerializer" = 2
  41.       "akka.remote.serialization.DaemonMsgCreateSerializer" = 3
  42.       "akka.remote.serialization.MessageContainerSerializer" = 6
  43.     }
  44.  
  45.     deployment {
  46.  
  47.       default {
  48.  
  49.         # if this is set to a valid remote address, the named actor will be
  50.         # deployed at that node e.g. "akka.tcp://sys@host:port"
  51.         remote = ""
  52.  
  53.         target {
  54.  
  55.           # A list of hostnames and ports for instantiating the children of a
  56.           # router
  57.           #   The format should be on "akka.tcp://sys@host:port", where:
  58.           #    - sys is the remote actor system name
  59.           #    - hostname can be either hostname or IP address the remote actor
  60.           #      should connect to
  61.           #    - port should be the port for the remote server on the other node
  62.           # The number of actor instances to be spawned is still taken from the
  63.           # nr-of-instances setting as for local routers; the instances will be
  64.           # distributed round-robin among the given nodes.
  65.           nodes = []
  66.  
  67.         }
  68.       }
  69.     }
  70.   }
  71.  
  72.   remote {
  73.  
  74.     ### General settings
  75.  
  76.     # Timeout after which the startup of the remoting subsystem is considered
  77.     # to be failed. Increase this value if your transport drivers (see the
  78.     # enabled-transports section) need longer time to be loaded.
  79.     startup-timeout = 10 s
  80.  
  81.     # Timout after which the graceful shutdown of the remoting subsystem is
  82.     # considered to be failed. After the timeout the remoting system is
  83.     # forcefully shut down. Increase this value if your transport drivers
  84.     # (see the enabled-transports section) need longer time to stop properly.
  85.     shutdown-timeout = 10 s
  86.  
  87.     # Before shutting down the drivers, the remoting subsystem attempts to flush
  88.     # all pending writes. This setting controls the maximum time the remoting is
  89.     # willing to wait before moving on to shut down the drivers.
  90.     flush-wait-on-shutdown = 2 s
  91.  
  92.     # Reuse inbound connections for outbound messages
  93.     use-passive-connections = on
  94.  
  95.     # Controls the backoff interval after a refused write is reattempted.
  96.     # (Transports may refuse writes if their internal buffer is full)
  97.     backoff-interval = 5 ms
  98.  
  99.     # Acknowledgment timeout of management commands sent to the transport stack.
  100.     command-ack-timeout = 30 s
  101.     
  102.     # The timeout for outbound associations to perform the handshake.
  103.     # If the transport is akka.remote.netty.tcp or akka.remote.netty.ssl
  104.     # the configured connection-timeout for the transport will be used instead.
  105.     handshake-timeout = 15 s
  106.  
  107.     # If set to a nonempty string remoting will use the given dispatcher for
  108.     # its internal actors otherwise the default dispatcher is used. Please note
  109.     # that since remoting can load arbitrary 3rd party drivers (see
  110.     # "enabled-transport" and "adapters" entries) it is not guaranteed that
  111.     # every module will respect this setting.
  112.     use-dispatcher = "akka.remote.default-remote-dispatcher"
  113.  
  114.     ### Security settings
  115.  
  116.     # Enable untrusted mode for full security of server managed actors, prevents
  117.     # system messages to be send by clients, e.g. messages like 'Create',
  118.     # 'Suspend', 'Resume', 'Terminate', 'Supervise', 'Link' etc.
  119.     untrusted-mode = off
  120.     
  121.     # When 'untrusted-mode=on' inbound actor selections are by default discarded.
  122.     # Actors with paths defined in this white list are granted permission to receive actor
  123.     # selections messages. 
  124.     # E.g. trusted-selection-paths = ["/user/receptionist", "/user/namingService"]   
  125.     trusted-selection-paths = []
  126.  
  127.     # Should the remote server require that its peers share the same
  128.     # secure-cookie (defined in the 'remote' section)? Secure cookies are passed
  129.     # between during the initial handshake. Connections are refused if the initial
  130.     # message contains a mismatching cookie or the cookie is missing.
  131.     require-cookie = off
  132.  
  133.     # Deprecated since 2.4-M1
  134.     secure-cookie = ""
  135.  
  136.     ### Logging
  137.  
  138.     # If this is "on", Akka will log all inbound messages at DEBUG level,
  139.     # if off then they are not logged
  140.     log-received-messages = off
  141.  
  142.     # If this is "on", Akka will log all outbound messages at DEBUG level,
  143.     # if off then they are not logged
  144.     log-sent-messages = off
  145.  
  146.     # Sets the log granularity level at which Akka logs remoting events. This setting
  147.     # can take the values OFF, ERROR, WARNING, INFO, DEBUG, or ON. For compatibility
  148.     # reasons the setting "on" will default to "debug" level. Please note that the effective
  149.     # logging level is still determined by the global logging level of the actor system:
  150.     # for example debug level remoting events will be only logged if the system
  151.     # is running with debug level logging.
  152.     # Failures to deserialize received messages also fall under this flag.
  153.     log-remote-lifecycle-events = on
  154.  
  155.     # Logging of message types with payload size in bytes larger than
  156.     # this value. Maximum detected size per message type is logged once,
  157.     # with an increase threshold of 10%.
  158.     # By default this feature is turned off. Activate it by setting the property to
  159.     # a value in bytes, such as 1000b. Note that for all messages larger than this
  160.     # limit there will be extra performance and scalability cost.
  161.     log-frame-size-exceeding = off
  162.     
  163.     # Log warning if the number of messages in the backoff buffer in the endpoint
  164.     # writer exceeds this limit. It can be disabled by setting the value to off.
  165.     log-buffer-size-exceeding = 50000
  166.  
  167.     ### Failure detection and recovery
  168.  
  169.     # Settings for the failure detector to monitor connections.
  170.     # For TCP it is not important to have fast failure detection, since
  171.     # most connection failures are captured by TCP itself. 
  172.     # The default DeadlineFailureDetector will trigger if there are no heartbeats within
  173.     # the duration heartbeat-interval + acceptable-heartbeat-pause, i.e. 20 seconds
  174.     # with the default settings.
  175.     transport-failure-detector {
  176.  
  177.       # FQCN of the failure detector implementation.
  178.       # It must implement akka.remote.FailureDetector and have
  179.       # a public constructor with a com.typesafe.config.Config and
  180.       # akka.actor.EventStream parameter.
  181.       implementation-class = "akka.remote.DeadlineFailureDetector"
  182.  
  183.       # How often keep-alive heartbeat messages should be sent to each connection.
  184.       heartbeat-interval = 4 s
  185.  
  186.       # Number of potentially lost/delayed heartbeats that will be
  187.       # accepted before considering it to be an anomaly.
  188.       # A margin to the `heartbeat-interval` is important to be able to survive sudden,
  189.       # occasional, pauses in heartbeat arrivals, due to for example garbage collect or
  190.       # network drop.
  191.       acceptable-heartbeat-pause = 16 s
  192.     }
  193.  
  194.     # Settings for the Phi accrual failure detector (http://www.jaist.ac.jp/~defago/files/pdf/IS_RR_2004_010.pdf
  195.     # [Hayashibara et al]) used for remote death watch.
  196.     # The default PhiAccrualFailureDetector will trigger if there are no heartbeats within
  197.     # the duration heartbeat-interval + acceptable-heartbeat-pause + threshold_adjustment,
  198.     # i.e. around 12.5 seconds with default settings.
  199.     watch-failure-detector {
  200.  
  201.       # FQCN of the failure detector implementation.
  202.       # It must implement akka.remote.FailureDetector and have
  203.       # a public constructor with a com.typesafe.config.Config and
  204.       # akka.actor.EventStream parameter.
  205.       implementation-class = "akka.remote.PhiAccrualFailureDetector"
  206.  
  207.       # How often keep-alive heartbeat messages should be sent to each connection.
  208.       heartbeat-interval = 1 s
  209.  
  210.       # Defines the failure detector threshold.
  211.       # A low threshold is prone to generate many wrong suspicions but ensures
  212.       # a quick detection in the event of a real crash. Conversely, a high
  213.       # threshold generates fewer mistakes but needs more time to detect
  214.       # actual crashes.
  215.       threshold = 10.0
  216.  
  217.       # Number of the samples of inter-heartbeat arrival times to adaptively
  218.       # calculate the failure timeout for connections.
  219.       max-sample-size = 200
  220.  
  221.       # Minimum standard deviation to use for the normal distribution in
  222.       # AccrualFailureDetector. Too low standard deviation might result in
  223.       # too much sensitivity for sudden, but normal, deviations in heartbeat
  224.       # inter arrival times.
  225.       min-std-deviation = 100 ms
  226.  
  227.       # Number of potentially lost/delayed heartbeats that will be
  228.       # accepted before considering it to be an anomaly.
  229.       # This margin is important to be able to survive sudden, occasional,
  230.       # pauses in heartbeat arrivals, due to for example garbage collect or
  231.       # network drop.
  232.       acceptable-heartbeat-pause = 10 s
  233.  
  234.  
  235.       # How often to check for nodes marked as unreachable by the failure
  236.       # detector
  237.       unreachable-nodes-reaper-interval = 1s
  238.  
  239.       # After the heartbeat request has been sent the first failure detection
  240.       # will start after this period, even though no heartbeat mesage has
  241.       # been received.
  242.       expected-response-after = 1 s
  243.  
  244.     }
  245.  
  246.     # After failed to establish an outbound connection, the remoting will mark the
  247.     # address as failed. This configuration option controls how much time should
  248.     # be elapsed before reattempting a new connection. While the address is
  249.     # gated, all messages sent to the address are delivered to dead-letters.
  250.     # Since this setting limits the rate of reconnects setting it to a
  251.     # very short interval (i.e. less than a second) may result in a storm of
  252.     # reconnect attempts.
  253.     retry-gate-closed-for = 5 s
  254.  
  255.     # After catastrophic communication failures that result in the loss of system
  256.     # messages or after the remote DeathWatch triggers the remote system gets
  257.     # quarantined to prevent inconsistent behavior.
  258.     # This setting controls how long the Quarantine marker will be kept around
  259.     # before being removed to avoid long-term memory leaks.
  260.     # WARNING: DO NOT change this to a small value to re-enable communication with
  261.     # quarantined nodes. Such feature is not supported and any behavior between
  262.     # the affected systems after lifting the quarantine is undefined.
  263.     prune-quarantine-marker-after = 5 d
  264.  
  265.     # If system messages have been exchanged between two systems (i.e. remote death
  266.     # watch or remote deployment has been used) a remote system will be marked as
  267.     # quarantined after the two system has no active association, and no
  268.     # communication happens during the time configured here.
  269.     # The only purpose of this setting is to avoid storing system message redelivery
  270.     # data (sequence number state, etc.) for an undefined amount of time leading to long
  271.     # term memory leak. Instead, if a system has been gone for this period,
  272.     # or more exactly
  273.     # - there is no association between the two systems (TCP connection, if TCP transport is used)
  274.     # - neither side has been attempting to communicate with the other
  275.     # - there are no pending system messages to deliver
  276.     # for the amount of time configured here, the remote system will be quarantined and all state
  277.     # associated with it will be dropped.
  278.     quarantine-after-silence = 5 d
  279.  
  280.     # This setting defines the maximum number of unacknowledged system messages
  281.     # allowed for a remote system. If this limit is reached the remote system is
  282.     # declared to be dead and its UID marked as tainted.
  283.     system-message-buffer-size = 20000
  284.  
  285.     # This setting defines the maximum idle time after an individual
  286.     # acknowledgement for system messages is sent. System message delivery
  287.     # is guaranteed by explicit acknowledgement messages. These acks are
  288.     # piggybacked on ordinary traffic messages. If no traffic is detected
  289.     # during the time period configured here, the remoting will send out
  290.     # an individual ack.
  291.     system-message-ack-piggyback-timeout = 0.3 s
  292.  
  293.     # This setting defines the time after internal management signals
  294.     # between actors (used for DeathWatch and supervision) that have not been
  295.     # explicitly acknowledged or negatively acknowledged are resent.
  296.     # Messages that were negatively acknowledged are always immediately
  297.     # resent.
  298.     resend-interval = 2 s
  299.     
  300.     # Maximum number of unacknowledged system messages that will be resent
  301.     # each 'resend-interval'. If you watch many (> 1000) remote actors you can
  302.     # increase this value to for example 600, but a too large limit (e.g. 10000)
  303.     # may flood the connection and might cause false failure detection to trigger.
  304.     # Test such a configuration by watching all actors at the same time and stop
  305.     # all watched actors at the same time.
  306.     resend-limit = 200
  307.  
  308.     # WARNING: this setting should not be not changed unless all of its consequences
  309.     # are properly understood which assumes experience with remoting internals
  310.     # or expert advice.
  311.     # This setting defines the time after redelivery attempts of internal management
  312.     # signals are stopped to a remote system that has been not confirmed to be alive by
  313.     # this system before.
  314.     initial-system-message-delivery-timeout = 3 m
  315.  
  316.     ### Transports and adapters
  317.  
  318.     # List of the transport drivers that will be loaded by the remoting.
  319.     # A list of fully qualified config paths must be provided where
  320.     # the given configuration path contains a transport-class key
  321.     # pointing to an implementation class of the Transport interface.
  322.     # If multiple transports are provided, the address of the first
  323.     # one will be used as a default address.
  324.     enabled-transports = ["akka.remote.netty.tcp"]
  325.  
  326.     # Transport drivers can be augmented with adapters by adding their
  327.     # name to the applied-adapters setting in the configuration of a
  328.     # transport. The available adapters should be configured in this
  329.     # section by providing a name, and the fully qualified name of
  330.     # their corresponding implementation. The class given here
  331.     # must implement akka.akka.remote.transport.TransportAdapterProvider
  332.     # and have public constructor without parameters.
  333.     adapters {
  334.       gremlin = "akka.remote.transport.FailureInjectorProvider"
  335.       trttl = "akka.remote.transport.ThrottlerProvider"
  336.     }
  337.  
  338.     ### Default configuration for the Netty based transport drivers
  339.  
  340.     netty.tcp {
  341.       # The class given here must implement the akka.remote.transport.Transport
  342.       # interface and offer a public constructor which takes two arguments:
  343.       #  1) akka.actor.ExtendedActorSystem
  344.       #  2) com.typesafe.config.Config
  345.       transport-class = "akka.remote.transport.netty.NettyTransport"
  346.  
  347.       # Transport drivers can be augmented with adapters by adding their
  348.       # name to the applied-adapters list. The last adapter in the
  349.       # list is the adapter immediately above the driver, while
  350.       # the first one is the top of the stack below the standard
  351.       # Akka protocol
  352.       applied-adapters = []
  353.  
  354.       transport-protocol = tcp
  355.  
  356.       # The default remote server port clients should connect to.
  357.       # Default is 2552 (AKKA), use 0 if you want a random available port
  358.       # This port needs to be unique for each actor system on the same machine.
  359.       port = 2552
  360.  
  361.       # The hostname or ip clients should connect to.
  362.       # InetAddress.getLocalHost.getHostAddress is used if empty
  363.       hostname = ""
  364.  
  365.       # Use this setting to bind a network interface to a different port
  366.       # than remoting protocol expects messages at. This may be used
  367.       # when running akka nodes in a separated networks (under NATs or docker containers).
  368.       # Use 0 if you want a random available port. Examples:
  369.       #
  370.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.port = 2552
  371.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.bind-port = 2553
  372.       # Network interface will be bound to the 2553 port, but remoting protocol will
  373.       # expect messages sent to port 2552.
  374.       #
  375.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.port = 0
  376.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.bind-port = 0
  377.       # Network interface will be bound to a random port, and remoting protocol will
  378.       # expect messages sent to the bound port.
  379.       #
  380.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.port = 2552
  381.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.bind-port = 0
  382.       # Network interface will be bound to a random port, but remoting protocol will
  383.       # expect messages sent to port 2552.
  384.       #
  385.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.port = 0
  386.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.bind-port = 2553
  387.       # Network interface will be bound to the 2553 port, and remoting protocol will
  388.       # expect messages sent to the bound port.
  389.       #
  390.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.port = 2552
  391.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.bind-port = ""
  392.       # Network interface will be bound to the 2552 port, and remoting protocol will
  393.       # expect messages sent to the bound port.
  394.       #
  395.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.port if empty
  396.       bind-port = ""
  397.  
  398.       # Use this setting to bind a network interface to a different hostname or ip
  399.       # than remoting protocol expects messages at.
  400.       # Use "0.0.0.0" to bind to all interfaces.
  401.       # akka.remote.netty.tcp.hostname if empty
  402.       bind-hostname = ""
  403.  
  404.       # Enables SSL support on this transport
  405.       enable-ssl = false
  406.  
  407.       # Sets the connectTimeoutMillis of all outbound connections,
  408.       # i.e. how long a connect may take until it is timed out
  409.       connection-timeout = 15 s
  410.  
  411.       # If set to "" then the specified dispatcher
  412.       # will be used to accept inbound connections, and perform IO. If "" then
  413.       # dedicated threads will be used.
  414.       # Please note that the Netty driver only uses this configuration and does
  415.       # not read the "akka.remote.use-dispatcher" entry. Instead it has to be
  416.       # configured manually to point to the same dispatcher if needed.
  417.       use-dispatcher-for-io = ""
  418.  
  419.       # Sets the high water mark for the in and outbound sockets,
  420.       # set to 0b for platform default
  421.       write-buffer-high-water-mark = 0b
  422.  
  423.       # Sets the low water mark for the in and outbound sockets,
  424.       # set to 0b for platform default
  425.       write-buffer-low-water-mark = 0b
  426.  
  427.       # Sets the send buffer size of the Sockets,
  428.       # set to 0b for platform default
  429.       send-buffer-size = 256000b
  430.  
  431.       # Sets the receive buffer size of the Sockets,
  432.       # set to 0b for platform default
  433.       receive-buffer-size = 256000b
  434.  
  435.       # Maximum message size the transport will accept, but at least
  436.       # 32000 bytes.
  437.       # Please note that UDP does not support arbitrary large datagrams,
  438.       # so this setting has to be chosen carefully when using UDP.
  439.       # Both send-buffer-size and receive-buffer-size settings has to
  440.       # be adjusted to be able to buffer messages of maximum size.
  441.       maximum-frame-size = 128000b
  442.  
  443.       # Sets the size of the connection backlog
  444.       backlog = 4096
  445.  
  446.       # Enables the TCP_NODELAY flag, i.e. disables Nagle’s algorithm
  447.       tcp-nodelay = on
  448.  
  449.       # Enables TCP Keepalive, subject to the O/S kernel’s configuration
  450.       tcp-keepalive = on
  451.  
  452.       # Enables SO_REUSEADDR, which determines when an ActorSystem can open
  453.       # the specified listen port (the meaning differs between *nix and Windows)
  454.       # Valid values are "on", "off" and "off-for-windows"
  455.       # due to the following Windows bug: http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4476378
  456.       # "off-for-windows" of course means that it's "on" for all other platforms
  457.       tcp-reuse-addr = off-for-windows
  458.  
  459.       # Used to configure the number of I/O worker threads on server sockets
  460.       server-socket-worker-pool {
  461.         # Min number of threads to cap factor-based number to
  462.         pool-size-min = 2
  463.  
  464.         # The pool size factor is used to determine thread pool size
  465.         # using the following formula: ceil(available processors * factor).
  466.         # Resulting size is then bounded by the pool-size-min and
  467.         # pool-size-max values.
  468.         pool-size-factor = 1.0
  469.  
  470.         # Max number of threads to cap factor-based number to
  471.         pool-size-max = 2
  472.       }
  473.  
  474.       # Used to configure the number of I/O worker threads on client sockets
  475.       client-socket-worker-pool {
  476.         # Min number of threads to cap factor-based number to
  477.         pool-size-min = 2
  478.  
  479.         # The pool size factor is used to determine thread pool size
  480.         # using the following formula: ceil(available processors * factor).
  481.         # Resulting size is then bounded by the pool-size-min and
  482.         # pool-size-max values.
  483.         pool-size-factor = 1.0
  484.  
  485.         # Max number of threads to cap factor-based number to
  486.         pool-size-max = 2
  487.       }
  488.  
  489.  
  490.     }
  491.  
  492.     netty.udp = ${akka.remote.netty.tcp}
  493.     netty.udp {
  494.       transport-protocol = udp
  495.     }
  496.  
  497.     netty.ssl = ${akka.remote.netty.tcp}
  498.     netty.ssl = {
  499.       # Enable SSL/TLS encryption.
  500.       # This must be enabled on both the client and server to work.
  501.       enable-ssl = true
  502.  
  503.       security {
  504.         # This is the Java Key Store used by the server connection
  505.         key-store = "keystore"
  506.  
  507.         # This password is used for decrypting the key store
  508.         key-store-password = "changeme"
  509.  
  510.         # This password is used for decrypting the key
  511.         key-password = "changeme"
  512.  
  513.         # This is the Java Key Store used by the client connection
  514.         trust-store = "truststore"
  515.  
  516.         # This password is used for decrypting the trust store
  517.         trust-store-password = "changeme"
  518.  
  519.         # Protocol to use for SSL encryption, choose from:
  520.         # Java 6 & 7:
  521.         #   'SSLv3', 'TLSv1'
  522.         # Java 7:
  523.         #   'TLSv1.1', 'TLSv1.2'
  524.         protocol = "TLSv1"
  525.  
  526.         # Example: ["TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA", "TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA"]
  527.         # You need to install the JCE Unlimited Strength Jurisdiction Policy
  528.         # Files to use AES 256.
  529.         # More info here:
  530.         # http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/security/SunProviders.html#SunJCEProvider
  531.         enabled-algorithms = ["TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA"]
  532.  
  533.         # There are three options, in increasing order of security:
  534.         # "" or SecureRandom => (default)
  535.         # "SHA1PRNG" => Can be slow because of blocking issues on Linux
  536.         # "AES128CounterSecureRNG" => fastest startup and based on AES encryption
  537.         # algorithm
  538.         # "AES256CounterSecureRNG"
  539.         #
  540.         # The following are deprecated in Akka 2.4. They use one of 3 possible
  541.         # seed sources, depending on availability: /dev/random, random.org and 
  542.         # SecureRandom (provided by Java)
  543.         # "AES128CounterInetRNG"
  544.         # "AES256CounterInetRNG" (Install JCE Unlimited Strength Jurisdiction
  545.         # Policy Files first)
  546.         # Setting a value here may require you to supply the appropriate cipher
  547.         # suite (see enabled-algorithms section above)
  548.         random-number-generator = ""
  549.       }
  550.     }
  551.  
  552.     ### Default configuration for the failure injector transport adapter
  553.  
  554.     gremlin {
  555.       # Enable debug logging of the failure injector transport adapter
  556.       debug = off
  557.     }
  558.  
  559.     ### Default dispatcher for the remoting subsystem
  560.  
  561.     default-remote-dispatcher {
  562.       type = Dispatcher
  563.       executor = "fork-join-executor"
  564.       fork-join-executor {
  565.         # Min number of threads to cap factor-based parallelism number to
  566.         parallelism-min = 2
  567.         parallelism-max = 2
  568.       }
  569.     }
  570.     
  571.     backoff-remote-dispatcher {
  572.       type = Dispatcher
  573.       executor = "fork-join-executor"
  574.       fork-join-executor {
  575.         # Min number of threads to cap factor-based parallelism number to
  576.         parallelism-min = 2
  577.         parallelism-max = 2
  578.       }
  579.     }
  580.  
  581.  
  582.   }
  583.  
  584. }

akka-testkit

  1. ######################################
  2. # Akka Testkit Reference Config File #
  3. ######################################
  4.  
  5. # This is the reference config file that contains all the default settings.
  6. # Make your edits/overrides in your application.conf.
  7.  
  8. akka {
  9.   test {
  10.     # factor by which to scale timeouts during tests, e.g. to account for shared
  11.     # build system load
  12.     timefactor =  1.0
  13.  
  14.     # duration of EventFilter.intercept waits after the block is finished until
  15.     # all required messages are received
  16.     filter-leeway = 3s
  17.  
  18.     # duration to wait in expectMsg and friends outside of within() block
  19.     # by default
  20.     single-expect-default = 3s
  21.  
  22.     # The timeout that is added as an implicit by DefaultTimeout trait
  23.     default-timeout = 5s
  24.  
  25.     calling-thread-dispatcher {
  26.       type = akka.testkit.CallingThreadDispatcherConfigurator
  27.     }
  28.   }
  29. }

akka-cluster-metrics ~~~~~~~~~~~~--------

  1. ##############################################
  2. # Akka Cluster Metrics Reference Config File #
  3. ##############################################
  4.  
  5. # This is the reference config file that contains all the default settings.
  6. # Make your edits in your application.conf in order to override these settings.
  7.  
  8. # Sigar provisioning:
  9. #
  10. #  User can provision sigar classes and native library in one of the following ways:
  11. # 
  12. #  1) Use https://github.com/kamon-io/sigar-loader Kamon sigar-loader as a project dependency for the user project.
  13. #  Metrics extension will extract and load sigar library on demand with help of Kamon sigar provisioner.
  14. # 
  15. #  2) Use https://github.com/kamon-io/sigar-loader Kamon sigar-loader as java agent: `java -javaagent:/path/to/sigar-loader.jar`
  16. #  Kamon sigar loader agent will extract and load sigar library during JVM start.
  17. # 
  18. #  3) Place `sigar.jar` on the `classpath` and sigar native library for the o/s on the `java.library.path`
  19. #  User is required to manage both project dependency and library deployment manually.
  20.  
  21. # Cluster metrics extension.
  22. # Provides periodic statistics collection and publication throughout the cluster.
  23. akka.cluster.metrics {
  24.     # Full path of dispatcher configuration key.
  25.     # Use "" for default key `akka.actor.default-dispatcher`.
  26.     dispatcher = ""
  27.     # How long should any actor wait before starting the periodic tasks.
  28.     periodic-tasks-initial-delay = 1s
  29.     # Sigar native library extract location.
  30.     # Use per-application-instance scoped location, such as program working directory.
  31.     native-library-extract-folder = ${user.dir}"/native"
  32.     # Metrics supervisor actor.
  33.     supervisor {
  34.         # Actor name. Example name space: /system/cluster-metrics
  35.         name = "cluster-metrics"
  36.         # Supervision strategy.
  37.         strategy {
  38.             #
  39.             # FQCN of class providing `akka.actor.SupervisorStrategy`.
  40.             # Must have a constructor with signature `(com.typesafe.config.Config)`.
  41.             # Default metrics strategy provider is a configurable extension of `OneForOneStrategy`.
  42.             provider = "akka.cluster.metrics.ClusterMetricsStrategy"
  43.             #
  44.             # Configuration of the default strategy provider.
  45.             # Replace with custom settings when overriding the provider.
  46.             configuration = {
  47.                 # Log restart attempts.
  48.                 loggingEnabled = true
  49.                 # Child actor restart-on-failure window.
  50.                 withinTimeRange = 3s
  51.                 # Maximum number of restart attempts before child actor is stopped.
  52.                 maxNrOfRetries = 3
  53.             }
  54.         }
  55.     }
  56.     # Metrics collector actor.
  57.     collector {
  58.         # Enable or disable metrics collector for load-balancing nodes.
  59.         # Metrics collection can also be controlled at runtime by sending control messages
  60.         # to /system/cluster-metrics actor: `akka.cluster.metrics.{CollectionStartMessage,CollectionStopMessage}`
  61.         enabled = on
  62.         # FQCN of the metrics collector implementation.
  63.         # It must implement `akka.cluster.metrics.MetricsCollector` and
  64.         # have public constructor with akka.actor.ActorSystem parameter.
  65.         # Will try to load in the following order of priority: 
  66.         # 1) configured custom collector 2) internal `SigarMetricsCollector` 3) internal `JmxMetricsCollector`
  67.         provider = ""
  68.         # Try all 3 available collector providers, or else fail on the configured custom collector provider.
  69.         fallback = true
  70.         # How often metrics are sampled on a node.
  71.         # Shorter interval will collect the metrics more often.
  72.         # Also controls frequency of the metrics publication to the node system event bus. 
  73.         sample-interval = 3s
  74.         # How often a node publishes metrics information to the other nodes in the cluster.
  75.         # Shorter interval will publish the metrics gossip more often.
  76.         gossip-interval = 3s
  77.         # How quickly the exponential weighting of past data is decayed compared to
  78.         # new data. Set lower to increase the bias toward newer values.
  79.         # The relevance of each data sample is halved for every passing half-life
  80.         # duration, i.e. after 4 times the half-life, a data sample’s relevance is
  81.         # reduced to 6% of its original relevance. The initial relevance of a data
  82.         # sample is given by 1 – 0.5 ^ (collect-interval / half-life).
  83.         # See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moving_average#Exponential_moving_average
  84.         moving-average-half-life = 12s
  85.     }
  86. }
  87.  
  88. # Cluster metrics extension serializers and routers.
  89. akka.actor {
  90.     # Protobuf serializer for remote cluster metrics messages.
  91.     serializers {
  92.        akka-cluster-metrics = "akka.cluster.metrics.protobuf.MessageSerializer"
  93.     }
  94.     # Interface binding for remote cluster metrics messages.
  95.     serialization-bindings {
  96.        "akka.cluster.metrics.ClusterMetricsMessage" = akka-cluster-metrics
  97.     }
  98.     # Globally unique metrics extension serializer identifier.
  99.     serialization-identifiers {
  100.       "akka.cluster.metrics.protobuf.MessageSerializer" = 10
  101.     }
  102.     #  Provide routing of messages based on cluster metrics.
  103.     router.type-mapping {
  104.         cluster-metrics-adaptive-pool  = "akka.cluster.metrics.AdaptiveLoadBalancingPool"
  105.         cluster-metrics-adaptive-group = "akka.cluster.metrics.AdaptiveLoadBalancingGroup"
  106.     }
  107. }

  79. # Settings for the ClusterClient
  80. akka.cluster.client {
  81.   # Actor paths of the ClusterReceptionist actors on the servers (cluster nodes)
  82.   # that the client will try to contact initially. It is mandatory to specify
  83.   # at least one initial contact. 
  84.   # Comma separated full actor paths defined by a string on the form of
  85.   # "akka.tcp://system@hostname:port/system/receptionist"
  86.   initial-contacts = []
  87.   
  88.   # Interval at which the client retries to establish contact with one of 
  89.   # ClusterReceptionist on the servers (cluster nodes)
  90.   establishing-get-contacts-interval = 3s
  91.   
  92.   # Interval at which the client will ask the ClusterReceptionist for
  93.   # new contact points to be used for next reconnect.
  94.   refresh-contacts-interval = 60s
  95.   
  96.   # How often failure detection heartbeat messages should be sent
  97.   heartbeat-interval = 2s
  98.   
  99.   # Number of potentially lost/delayed heartbeats that will be
  100.   # accepted before considering it to be an anomaly.
  101.   # The ClusterClient is using the akka.remote.DeadlineFailureDetector, which
  102.   # will trigger if there are no heartbeats within the duration 
  103.   # heartbeat-interval + acceptable-heartbeat-pause, i.e. 15 seconds with
  104.   # the default settings.
  105.   acceptable-heartbeat-pause = 13s
  106.   
  107.   # If connection to the receptionist is not established the client will buffer
  108.   # this number of messages and deliver them the connection is established.
  109.   # When the buffer is full old messages will be dropped when new messages are sent
  110.   # via the client. Use 0 to disable buffering, i.e. messages will be dropped
  111.   # immediately if the location of the singleton is unknown.
  112.   # Maximum allowed buffer size is 10000.
  113.   buffer-size = 1000
  114. }

  136.   # If the role is not specified it's a singleton among all nodes in the cluster.

  140.   # that might be leaving the cluster. This is retried with this interval until

  142.   # oldest member is removed from the cluster (+ akka.cluster.down-removal-margin).
  143.   hand-over-retry-interval = 1s

  146.   # akka.cluster.down-removal-margin (or ClusterSingletonManagerSettings.removalMargin),
  147.   # but it will never be less than this property.

akka-cluster-sharding ~~~~~~~~~~~~---------

  1. ###############################################
  2. # Akka Cluster Sharding Reference Config File #
  3. ###############################################
  4.  
  5. # This is the reference config file that contains all the default settings.
  6. # Make your edits/overrides in your application.conf.
  7.  
  8.  
  9. # //#sharding-ext-config
  10. # Settings for the ClusterShardingExtension
  11. akka.cluster.sharding {
  12.  
  13.   # The extension creates a top level actor with this name in top level system scope,
  14.   # e.g. '/system/sharding'
  15.   guardian-name = sharding
  16.  
  17.   # Specifies that entities runs on cluster nodes with a specific role.
  18.   # If the role is not specified (or empty) all nodes in the cluster are used.
  19.   role = ""
  20.  
  21.   # When this is set to 'on' the active entity actors will automatically be restarted
  22.   # upon Shard restart. i.e. if the Shard is started on a different ShardRegion
  23.   # due to rebalance or crash.
  24.   remember-entities = off
  25.  
  26.   # If the coordinator can't store state changes it will be stopped
  27.   # and started again after this duration, with an exponential back-off
  28.   # of up to 5 times this duration.
  29.   coordinator-failure-backoff = 5 s
  30.  
  31.   # The ShardRegion retries registration and shard location requests to the
  32.   # ShardCoordinator with this interval if it does not reply.
  33.   retry-interval = 2 s
  34.  
  35.   # Maximum number of messages that are buffered by a ShardRegion actor.
  36.   buffer-size = 100000
  37.  
  38.   # Timeout of the shard rebalancing process.
  39.   handoff-timeout = 60 s
  40.  
  41.   # Time given to a region to acknowledge it's hosting a shard.
  42.   shard-start-timeout = 10 s
  43.  
  44.   # If the shard is remembering entities and can't store state changes
  45.   # will be stopped and then started again after this duration. Any messages
  46.   # sent to an affected entity may be lost in this process.
  47.   shard-failure-backoff = 10 s
  48.  
  49.   # If the shard is remembering entities and an entity stops itself without
  50.   # using passivate. The entity will be restarted after this duration or when
  51.   # the next message for it is received, which ever occurs first.
  52.   entity-restart-backoff = 10 s
  53.  
  54.   # Rebalance check is performed periodically with this interval.
  55.   rebalance-interval = 10 s
  56.  
  57.   # Absolute path to the journal plugin configuration entity that is to be
  58.   # used for the internal persistence of ClusterSharding. If not defined
  59.   # the default journal plugin is used. Note that this is not related to
  60.   # persistence used by the entity actors.
  61.   journal-plugin-id = ""
  62.  
  63.   # Absolute path to the snapshot plugin configuration entity that is to be
  64.   # used for the internal persistence of ClusterSharding. If not defined
  65.   # the default snapshot plugin is used. Note that this is not related to
  66.   # persistence used by the entity actors.
  67.   snapshot-plugin-id = ""
  68.  
  69.   # Parameter which determines how the coordinator will be store a state
  70.   # valid values either "persistence" or "ddata"
  71.   # The "ddata" mode is experimental, since it depends on the experimental
  72.   # module akka-distributed-data-experimental.
  73.   state-store-mode = "persistence"
  74.  
  75.   # The shard saves persistent snapshots after this number of persistent
  76.   # events. Snapshots are used to reduce recovery times.
  77.   snapshot-after = 1000
  78.  
  79.   # Setting for the default shard allocation strategy
  80.   least-shard-allocation-strategy {
  81.     # Threshold of how large the difference between most and least number of
  82.     # allocated shards must be to begin the rebalancing.
  83.     rebalance-threshold = 10
  84.  
  85.     # The number of ongoing rebalancing processes is limited to this number.
  86.     max-simultaneous-rebalance = 3
  87.   }
  88.  
  89.   # Timeout of waiting the initial distributed state (an initial state will be queried again if the timeout happened)
  90.   # works only for state-store-mode = "ddata"
  91.   waiting-for-state-timeout = 5 s
  92.  
  93.   # Timeout of waiting for update the distributed state (update will be retried if the timeout happened)
  94.   # works only for state-store-mode = "ddata"
  95.   updating-state-timeout = 5 s
  96.  
  97.   # Settings for the coordinator singleton. Same layout as akka.cluster.singleton.
  98.   coordinator-singleton = ${akka.cluster.singleton}
  99.  
  100.   # The id of the dispatcher to use for ClusterSharding actors.
  101.   # If not specified default dispatcher is used.
  102.   # If specified you need to define the settings of the actual dispatcher.
  103.   # This dispatcher for the entity actors is defined by the user provided
  104.   # Props, i.e. this dispatcher is not used for the entity actors.
  105.   use-dispatcher = ""
  106. }
  107. # //#sharding-ext-config
  108.  
  109.  
  110. # Protobuf serializer for Cluster Sharding messages
  111. akka.actor {
  112.   serializers {
  113.     akka-sharding = "akka.cluster.sharding.protobuf.ClusterShardingMessageSerializer"
  114.   }
  115.   serialization-bindings {
  116.     "akka.cluster.sharding.ClusterShardingSerializable" = akka-sharding
  117.   }
  118.   serialization-identifiers {
  119.     "akka.cluster.sharding.protobuf.ClusterShardingMessageSerializer" = 13
  120.   }
  121. }

  35.   # removed cluster nodes.

  39.   # This is used when initiating and completing the pruning process of data associated

  41.   # unreachable, so it should be configured to worst case in a healthy cluster.
  42.   max-pruning-dissemination = 60 s
  43.   
  44.   # Serialized Write and Read messages are cached when they are sent to 
  45.   # several nodes. If no further activity they are removed from the cache
  46.   # after this duration.
  47.   serializer-cache-time-to-live = 10s
